title: here is a crazy thought... what if supports could farm?
body:
after season 6 (which i mained support for like 95% of my 400 ish games i know not a lot)
and now going into toplane with splitpushers i came to a conclusion.

the priorities that will win you a game consistently is if you follow the following 4 step strat


step 1 
kill the nexus.
step 2
to get there kill minions/push wave to tower
step 3 
kill turrets and inhib
step 4 kill enemy champs if they get in the way.

if everyone on your team follows this strat you are sure to win... and most champions have tools that benefit steps 1 through 4

yet supports the genuine ones like for example {{champion:201}} have very little in their kits to help them in step 1 through 3.
and even with step 4 they are DEPENDENT ON THEIR TEAM.

ow btw you get the least amount of gold also.

so how about we give supports more ways to contribute in their ability to control lanes.
controlling lanes is essential to winning this game yet most supports don't have the tools to control lanes 
they are a single minded cc bot.

the only thing we really have is {{item:3512}} but thats an item everyone can get that. our kits are the real problem as is the fact that we cant really farm/control lanes.

replies.body:
When I first played this game, I thought last-hitting was a terrible mini-game.  Really didn't enjoy it at all.  After thousands of games, I've found that not only do I enjoy it, but so many of players' interactions only get to happen because of the focus on managing the creeps.  

We've also created some really rich farming patterns on champions that keep them feeling lively.  It's a bit of a shame that supports don't get to partake in a lot of that. I get to play the creep game by proxy: help my marksmen get the last hit, try to stop the opposition from it.  But it's a pain whenever I'm alone in a lane because I'm so bad at killing creeps.  

I think your'e onto something. But if we were to load more power into creep management and turret taking for supports, how many people would actually appreciate that?

>I think your'e onto something. But if we were to load more power into creep management and turret taking for supports, how many people would actually appreciate that?

Given how the average person feels about support right now how much do you stand to lose?

We'd just lose the opportunity cost, I suppose.  Think we've already signed up to look into making them more fun. If we load a bunch of power into CSing and pushing, it would likely mean we're not exploring something else.  

Anywho, this thread is a bit of preaching to the choir when I'm listening. I love creep management and tower taking.

The REAL issue I think is where would this farm the support gets come from? There's the 3 lanes for Top, MId, and ADC and the neutral mobs for Jungle. 4 sources of income for 5 players. If you created a reliable source of income that supports could manage on their own, what would prevent players who are simply better at farming(i.e. everyone else) from abusing it to push their farm even more ahead, thus still denying the support the ability to farm? 

I think that's the biggest issue. You have gold income items to provide income for supports, but they naturally have to be relatively bad so that other roles don't see a reason to pick them up. Whatever is devised for supports to "farm" is naturally going to suffer from the same implications as gold income items.

You could just make it like {{item:3302}} if an allied champion is in range that champion gains the gold of all minions killed and you could add that to all the support items (and relic shield could just have when having stacks you also gain the gold from minions killed) 

this would allow supports to more easily push and "farm" without hurting their ADC... but well a lot of them would still be bad at pushing and farming (especially melee tank supports)

While you have a very good point i think this can be solved by making the sight stone the supports equivalent of the jng items, except in reverse.  So as long as the player has a sight stone they get the ability to play the support mini-game (whatever that might be).

The thing is, though, that jungle items are tied to having smite. Which is more or less a requirement of the jungle. If its simply tied to sight stone, someone else can still pick up an early sight stone to net the extra farm and sell it later when they've gotten their fill of gold from it. Sure, someone who is in lane can grab smite, but without actively killing jungle monsters, the extra gold is relatively useless. It's a complex issue for sure, but I do hope a reasonable solution is created. 

The other issue with this is: When supports get reasonable gold, what's going to prevent them from just rolling into another carry? Most of them do it now anyways, but it's delayed due to their lack of gold. Support items simply aren't attractive enough to pick up for most players.

The issue is.... how do you tie it to the role? It's not as easy as just locking it into someone who queued for support. Then you get the issue of team comps wherein I let my mid laner queue for support and just trade roles with him and he snowballs early due to the extra income. It's a bit more difficult.

What about a support item that helps you waveclear (some sort of bonus damage to minions?), but instead of getting gold yourself, drops a gem that your allies can pick up? To avoid abuse, you'd get less gold from killing minions (on par with the coin line, maybe more), and the gem will disappear after a while.

Well, it is true, innit? You can't carry with Braum no matter how hard you try. He doesn't clear waves, nor does he takes towers. He can at most ZZ Rot (one of my favourite Support items for this very reason).

There is a reason why midlaners such as Brand and Malzahar are so popular "Support" picks, because in return of playing Support early game they can later just go full midlaner-mode and carry like usual.

The thing is though that there are no challenging mini-games for supports at all. No objectives for them to contest in the map, no self-viability, no wave clear potential (Redemption is not enough), nothing.

Helping your team with shields and heals and map awareness is great, yet quite passive. 

I assume people would prefer if the support role was more proactive, instead of reactive (e.g. clearing a huge wave since 3 teammates are dead and the other one is managing to hold another lane against 2 people).

One interesting "mini-game" of the support role that I do enjoy, is the fact that you can pick a champ that comboes with your ADC counterpart. Unfortunately (or fortunately), people pick the champs they are most comfortable with and sometimes neglect this.

Also if my teammates die and waves are closing in on our base, Support is the absolute worst role to be in since they have no way of defending the base.

Support feels terrible because the entire role lacks power in the things that actually matter - controlling lanes, clearing waves to push, dealing damage to objectives. Even as CC bots, that only matters when picking off a lone splitpusher or in a big team fight and it's not like the Support can actually follow up on their own CC to do something useful. 

When self-reliant generalists are Meta (and they are almost always Meta in Solo Queue) then Supports just lose a lot of value on top of being not that fun to play. Giving them something more interesting to do in lane besides watching carries last-hit safely from range and occasionally casting a spell of two to poke or engage/disengage a trade if one carry is feeling ballsy.

I dont Support often - but I remeber some pretty funny lanes supporting a Kalista - her ability to mark CS for the supp to lasthit was really funny and helpfull sometimes. ^^ 
A feature similar to this could really improove the fealing of bot lane - as a mastery? maybe?

What if someone were to think that last-hitting is still a terrible minigame after too many hours in LOL?

PS.  I miss old Soraka's ability to shove waves in.

I like trading around the enemy trying to last hit. Hitting an enemy champion is a lot more rewarding to me than hitting a minion. The only time I care about farm is when my team is AWOL and there are super minions pushing my base.

As a support, I hate setting minions up for my partners - especially under turret. It might seem novel at first, but later on it just feels like a chore. Supports don't need to CS, just balance them around that.

I feel like It may make the role more attractive to not only support mains but people that don't normally play support. The reason people don't like the role as much is because it's 10x's harder to carry as a support than it is any other lane, so it'd be nice if it felt like maybe we had more a One-Man impact on the game than what we have now; which in most cases is sitting back hoping you feed your laner or pray laning phase ends quickly so you can go support the best off person on your team. And if they're all doing bad? Well.. just wtf lol 

Idk if the solution to this is letting supports farm more, but I do think there should at least be more gold generation in some manner for supports. I honestly feel all of the starting options are sub-par in regards to gold, one way or another, unless it's {{item:3301}} but who wants to give up the shared minions on {{item:3097}} (with it's later active) or the aggro gold from {{item:3303}} with it's possible actives as well.

I feel like this is comparable to raising the minimum wage of supports LOL

I don't think that would be the best path to take, since it would mean it would eat into the gold income of other team members.  I think a better path would be looking to give them more power out of champion combat, namely taking objectives.  Supports really can't do anything like take jungle monsters or kill towers.  The only thing they can do is buff their allies.  This takes away agency from the support player, which is part of why it is so unsatisfying to play.  Another important step would be to push the vision game further into a teamwide task rather than focusing so heavily on the support role.  Removing the requirement to purchase Sighstone as well could help, considering it eats up 800 gold of an already limited budget.

That being said, giving supports some ability to clear waves isn't a bad idea.  It's kind of sad watching supports try to fight off waves by themselves and be unable to turn them back.  Similar wave clear ability to many tank top laners would be plenty sufficient.  Not enough that they start eating up waves, but just enough that they feel like a champion and not a heal / CC bot.

It's kind of a shame that supports don't take part in the last-hitting mini-game, since it adds a ton of depth to the laning phase.  They get other jobs though, and I think that having a lane role without last-hitting is important.  Each role should feel meaningfully different.  Top lane is a more passive and typically tanky 1v1 lane, mid is a high damage squishy 1v1 lane, ADC is a low experience but high gold income high-damage ranged 2v2 lane, support is a low-resource utility heavy 2v2 lane, and jungle is a PVE and map pressure focused role.  Each role is very distinct (top and mid are the most similar, but play very differently and typically have very different roles), catering to different types of players.  Those who love tanks play top, jungle, and support; and among those, there are different options based on if you prefer a 1v1, PVE and roaming, or a completely supportive role.

I mean are you exaggerating here or does it really take that long? If it is taking that long, I feel you are doing something wrong.

I play Bard, so I'm most familiar with him, and his waveclear is usable early game and really good late game.

Let's say for some reason I'm by myself level 1 and need to clear a wave. I'm going to Q the caster minions first, hitting two of them, and then finish them off with autoattacks, one of which will be empowered. Then I carefully time my autoattacks to minimize the time the remaining creeps live. 
Hitting the casters first does a couple things for me. They have less HP, so they take less time. But they also do more damage, so by finishing them first, I minimize the amount of damage my own creep wave takes, which means it survives longer to help me push.

If I'm trying to set up a mega wave, so that the lane will auto-push, I will kill only the caster minions, and then walk away. This stalls my wave while allowing some members of it to survive so it will overpower the next enemy minion wave when the next friendly minion wave catches up. Resulting in a slow-push, and allowing me to leave the lane and go help my team. Eventually that wave will represent a threat to the enemy tower and a large loss of gold if the enemy ignores it. If they go to deal with it, they are down a team member and we have a better fight somewhere else on the map.
